    <item>
      <title>Look out, Katie Hopkins, Azealia Banks is on the mic</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/lostinshowbiz/2016/may/12/azealia-banks-zayn-malik-katie-hopkins-one-direction</link>
      <description><p>The rapper was axed by a UK festival after a Twitter fight with Zayn Malik this week – it could be the start of a new career as a tabloid columnist</p><p>Our thoughts at this difficult time must be passed to part-time musician turned full-time Steve Brookstein Twitter account tribute act Azealia Banks, who has <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/music/2016/may/11/azealia-banks-axed-uk-music-festival-zayn-malik-twitter" title="">been dropped by a London festival</a> that she was due to headline next month, all because she happens to be an objectively terrible person with no redeeming qualities.</p><p>Chances are you already know the events that kicked this all off. Banks initially claimed that Zayn Malik had plagiarised a video of hers, then, when he later tweeted something vague and unrelated at nobody in particular, launched into a vicious and sustained attack – both racist and homophobic – that lasted for several hours, expanded to take in the entire British music industry, then collapsed in on itself in a series of exhausted, strangulated yelps. The tweets have since been deleted, but the damage had already been done.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/lostinshowbiz/2016/may/12/azealia-banks-zayn-malik-katie-hopkins-one-direction">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <title>Dating, dentist, debt: draw the struggles of your adult life</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/2016/may/12/dating-dentist-debt-draw-the-struggles-of-your-adult-life</link>
      <description><p>Being an adult is no walk in the park – in fact it sometimes feel more like a nauseating rollercoaster rider. Share your struggles with us through drawings<br></p><p>When you’re a kid, no one tells you how tough being an adult is going to be.</p><p>There’s the endless (failed) attempts to budget, successfully organise nights out, wash clothes, cook, sustain/ find relationships, pay bills – and all this must be done while trying not to get fired. <br></p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/2016/may/12/dating-dentist-debt-draw-the-struggles-of-your-adult-life">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>'If you don't talk, it doesn't work': how sport helps autistic people</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/2016/may/12/how-sport-helps-autistic-people-effective-treatment-autism</link>
      <description><p>The intrinsic importance of social skills in sport means it can be a more effective treatment than traditional therapy</p><p> “A few years ago, I couldn’t even go out of the house by myself,” says Daniel Mynott. That was before he started getting involved in sport. “Now, I go all over London and the country. I have so many friends I’ve lost count. I even have my own car.”</p><p>Mynott has autism. A few years ago, when he was 15, <a href="http://www.thechangefoundation.org.uk/">the Change Foundation</a> turned up at his school and encouraged him to try taking part in sport. “I hated sport,” he says. “I was lazy as hell, but they saw my potential, they saw I was good with people. Gradually, I fell in love with it.”<br></p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/2016/may/12/how-sport-helps-autistic-people-effective-treatment-autism">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>I’m an older mother – and I bloody love it</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/shortcuts/2016/may/11/being-an-older-mother-i-love-it</link>
      <description><p>The news that a 70-year-old Indian woman has given birth has surprised the world and brought the spotlight on older mums. Guardian columnist Luisa Dillner had a baby at 48 – here, she extols the joys of late motherhood <br></p><p>I’m still summoning up the courage to tell my daughter how old I am. At six, I think Flora suspects. She keeps asking me – and I keep deflecting her. “So what do you want for your birthday?” Or: “Let’s skip down the road.” We need a proper conversation, not just a number. I need to tell her why I’m older than other mothers at her school (and after writing this, I had better get on with it). But goodness me, I’m not as old as <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/world/2016/may/10/indian-woman-in-her-70s-gives-birth-to-healthy-baby-boy">Daljinder Kaur, who is reported to have given birth last month at 70</a>. She had two years of treatment using donor eggs from the National Fertility and Test Tube Baby Centre in Hisar, in India’s northern state of Haryana. Kaur is quoted as saying: “I feel so full of energy.”</p><p>Now, I’m not going to cast aspersions on any woman’s right to have a baby (or even if the reports are accurate). How could I? Kaur may be older than me, but her egg would have been younger than mine.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/shortcuts/2016/may/11/being-an-older-mother-i-love-it">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>How much should you spend on a wedding gift?</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/2016/may/11/how-much-should-you-spend-on-a-wedding-gift</link>
      <description><p>Everyone is talking about the wedding guest who was rebuked for not spending enough on a couple’s big day. So, what should you give?<br></p><p>A post on <a href="http://www.mumsnet.com/Talk/mumsnet_classics/2630932-Post-wedding-message-please-help-me-what-the-hell-do-I-say?pg=10">Mumsnet </a> has got everyone talking. It involves an unnamed wedding guest, who gave a couple £100 as a gift, only to be rebuked by the newlyweds for not being generous enough. <br></p><p>Although the details are patchy (and we are only hearing one side of the story), it has prompted an interesting debate: how much should you spend on a wedding gift? We asked our readers and here’s what they said (spoiler: it may be less than you’d think).<br tabindex="-1"></p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/2016/may/11/how-much-should-you-spend-on-a-wedding-gift">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Cycling: how to ride in a group</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/2016/may/11/cycling-how-ride-group-peloton</link>
      <description><p>The thrill of riding in a bunch, working together to draft and save energy, is one of the joys of cycling – but it can be daunting … and sometimes dangerous </p><p>There’s something beautiful about cycling in a big bunch, with individual riders working together like birds in formation. Reduced drag has a big effect, too, of course, allowing you to ride faster for the same effort.</p><p>Knowing a few basic techniques and etiquette tips will keep you safer, and make you a welcome member of the peloton.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/2016/may/11/cycling-how-ride-group-peloton">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>It's spring: stop using your dryer already</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/2016/may/10/its-spring-stop-using-your-dryer-clothesline</link>
      <description><p>The sweet ritual of hanging your clothes to dry in the warmth of the sun is not only environmentally effective, it’ll spare your clothes undue damage</p><p>Everyone hates me in the springtime. </p><p>As soon as the weather warms up, the clothesline in my backyard gets hauled into action and I become physically unable to stop talking about it. My Instagram feed becomes littered with bucolic pictures of my dainties fluttering in the sunny breeze and I become prone to embarking upon long-winded screeds to anyone within earshot about how amazing my sheets smell when they’re dried in the fresh air. <br>In the wintertime, my clothes stagnate in the hamper until it risks overflowing or until my daughter runs out of socks. In spring and summer, however, I’m a compulsive laundry-doer. A sunny day means a laundry day, and laundry days fill me with an embarrassing amount of glee. </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/2016/may/10/its-spring-stop-using-your-dryer-clothesline">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>The ‘perfect body’ is a lie. I believed it for a long time and let it shrink my life</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/2016/may/08/perfect-body-lie-believed-long-time-let-shrink-my-life-lindy-west</link>
      <description><p>As a child, Lindy West was told she was ‘off the charts’. In this exclusive extract from her new book, Shrill, she explains how society’s fixation on thinness warps women’s lives – and why she would rather be ‘fat’ than ‘big’</p><p>I’ve always been a great big person. In the months after I was born, the doctor was so alarmed by the circumference of my head that she insisted my parents bring me back, over and over, to be weighed and measured and held up for scrutiny next to the “normal” babies. My head was “off the charts”, she said. Science literally had not produced a chart expansive enough to account for my monster dome. “Off the charts” became a West family joke over the years – I always deflected it, saying it was because of my giant brain – but I absorbed the message nonetheless. I was too big, from birth. Abnormally big. Medical-anomaly big. Unchartably big.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/2016/may/08/perfect-body-lie-believed-long-time-let-shrink-my-life-lindy-west">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Why is finding a therapist so hard? Meet the mental health matchmaker</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/2016/may/09/finding-good-therapist-matchmaker-mental-health</link>
      <description><p>Finding someone to connect with can be draining – much like dating – and Dr David Kelley wants to help. <strong>Jean Hannah Edelstein</strong> investigates</p><p>“You should try therapy!” is a suggestion that I realized, after maybe too long, most people don’t take as a compliment. I think therapy is great: what thoughtful, smart person wouldn’t benefit from taking some time for careful examination of their feelings and how they interact with the world? No thoughtful, smart person, in my opinion. Deciding to go to therapy isn’t an admission of fault: it’s an admission of the desire to be happier, less anxious and more at ease.</p><p>But even if you are the kind of thoughtful, smart person who can overcome the stigma against seeing a professional to talk about your problems, there’s another major hurdle to surmount: it can be very difficult to find the <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/2016/may/02/therpist-client-relationship-breakup">right therapist</a>. Much as with dating, for therapy to succeed, you need to find someone with whom you want to spend a lot of time talking about yourself (unlike dating, however, you should definitely not have sex with your therapist). As with dating, looking online (<a href="https://therapists.psychologytoday.com/rms/?utm_source=PT_Psych_Today&amp;utm_medium=House_Link&amp;utm_campaign=PT_HomeTopB_find">Psychology Today</a> has the most popular database) and going through a trial and error process can be emotionally draining, especially if you’re feeling sad or anxious already and lack the energy to interview a lot of different therapists before you hit the right one.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/2016/may/09/finding-good-therapist-matchmaker-mental-health">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Growing pains: are perfect families a recipe for stress?</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/2016/may/08/perfect-families-stress-exhaustion-modern-parents</link>
      <description><p>Vanessa Thorpe speaks to three couples about the exhaustion of being modern parents – and expert Tony Crabbe offers his suggestions</p><p>It was tough finding time to write this piece, what with the children, the emails, the laundry, the meetings, the phone calls. Want to know more about my struggle? No, I bet you don’t. We have all listened to frenzied itineraries from parents who also hold down a job and who evidently hope to impress and inspire sympathy in equal measure. The truth is that many of Britain’s families are in the same beleaguered state. More mothers and fathers than ever are tired out yet believe that’s just how it is.</p><p>The findings of January’s <a href="http://www.workingfamilies.org.uk/wp-content/uploads/2016/02/Modern-Families-Index-2016.pdf">Modern Families Index</a> show that almost a third (29%) of the nation’s parents are complaining of burnout, not just from long hours at work but from toiling at home. Domestic chores and the logistics of children’s aspirational hobbies mean more than a third (35%) of those asked by the charity <a href="http://www.workingfamilies.org.uk">Working Families</a> believe they are chasing their tails in a race they do not remember entering. Annual leave is regarded as a coping mechanism, many said, and 28% of parents admitted faking sickness to deal with hectic lives.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/2016/may/08/perfect-families-stress-exhaustion-modern-parents">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <title>In praise of the Queen | Katharine Whitehorn</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/2016/may/09/in-praise-of-the-queen-katharine-whitehorn</link>
      <description><p>For anybody who has grown up with the Queen, the ‘new Elizabethan age’ has been something to celebrate</p><p>Those of us who are nearly her age can remember the Queen’s ascension to the throne and the cheerful delight with which people talked of the “New Elizabethan age”. Her coronation fitted well with the postwar feeling that we had won the war and we were now going to make sure we had a splendid new Britain with this attractive figurehead.</p><p>The word “coronation” got attached to all sorts of unlikely things – we still call a certain curried dish “coronation chicken”. An attractive young lady taking the throne as the country came to light again after the war seemed perfect.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/2016/may/09/in-praise-of-the-queen-katharine-whitehorn">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>RIP the nightclub era, and my lovely memories of youth</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/global/commentisfree/2016/may/07/death-of-nightclubs-internet-dating-eva-wiseman</link>
      <description>Back in the 90s our columnist spent her evenings selling nipple tassels at the Whoopee Club. Now she laments the death of the dancefloor in today’s Britain<p>It is pure coincidence that the death of nightclubs has been announced at the same time as the demise of my youth. Send no flowers. There was a time when I would live for Friday nights, for the hair-doing, the bus-getting, the queue-jumping. For the crush and stickiness of a room under a dual-carriageway, full of beer and tongues. But mine is the last generation to know the nightclub, that particular thrill of the morning after, the echo in your ears.</p><p>Across Britain we’re losing a club a month. Discos are now Tescos. Last summer <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2015/aug/11/clubs-closing-nightlife-uk" title="">new statistics</a> suggested an epidemic – in 2005 there were 3,144 nightclubs in the UK; in 2015 there were 1,733. The nighttime is changing shape. The reasons why are manifold and odd. Across cities, the demand for space means venues that might have previously welcomed a coach of sweaty dancers are now blocks of many-windowed flats.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/global/commentisfree/2016/may/07/death-of-nightclubs-internet-dating-eva-wiseman">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Could children one day sue parents for posting baby pics on Facebook?</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/sustainable-business/2016/may/08/children-sue-parents-facebook-post-baby-photos-privacy</link>
      <description><p>Pictures once kept hidden in family photo albums are now being shared with the world, and children may not appreciate it in the future</p><p>That photo of your toddler running around in a nappy or having a temper tantrum? Think before you post it on Facebook. That’s the advice from French authorities, which have warned parents in France they <a draggable="true" href="http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/europe/france/12179584/French-parents-could-be-jailed-for-posting-childrens-photos-online.html">could face fines</a> of up to €45,000 (£35,000) and a year in prison for publishing intimate photos of their children on social media without permission, as part of the country’s strict privacy laws. </p><p>It’s a development that could give pause for thought for many parents used to sharing details of their children’s lives across social media. A <a draggable="true" href="http://www.nominet.uk/todays-children-will-feature-in-almost-1000-online-photos-by-the-time-they-reach-age-five/">2015 study</a> by internet company Nominet found parents in the UK post nearly 200 photos of their under fives online every year, meaning a child will feature in around 1,000 online photos before their fifth birthday. </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/sustainable-business/2016/may/08/children-sue-parents-facebook-post-baby-photos-privacy">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Time is money. But which is better? | Ben Ambridge</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/2016/may/08/quiz-time-money-better-ben-ambridge</link>
      <description><p>We all know how valuable our time is... but would you rather have more time or more money? Take this quiz to find out</p><p><strong>Imagine you are given the opportunity to change the arrangements of your current job. Would you rather: a) work fewer hours and make less money or b) work more hours and make more money?</strong></p><p>If you said a) then good news: a study published this year found that people who value time over money tend to be happier. Across six experiments – with university students, museum visitors, and respondents to an online survey – researchers found that the people who think it’s better to have more time than more money gave higher scores on questionnaire-based measures of happiness.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/2016/may/08/quiz-time-money-better-ben-ambridge">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Always look on the bright side? Surely a route to disaster</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/global/commentisfree/2016/may/07/un-media-positive-news-catherine-bennett</link>
      <description>The UN thinks the media doesn’t offer a rounded picture, and need to be in the business of ‘constructive’ news<p>First, the bad news: the <em>New Day</em>, after two months in existence, has become the latest British newspaper to vanish, with an <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/media/2016/may/05/mirror-journalists-fear-cuts-to-cover-secretive-new-day-costs" title="">“inevitable”</a> loss of jobs. Since the newspaper’s selling point was, as the title suggests, its resolutely cheerful take on current events, this might also look like a setback for advocates of more positive news coverage. Its editor, Alison Phillips, had promised readers: “We’ll tell you everything you need to know and we won’t sensationalise or terrify you with the news.” So Trinity Mirror has nothing to apologise for. We are probably all to blame. You could see the concept working brilliantly in Beijing.</p><p>But now some good news. Princess Charlotte has a hamster called Marvin. Sir David Attenborough is 90. Scotland is getting an <a href="http://www.edinburghnews.scotsman.com/news/lothian-pooches-finalists-to-be-visitscotland-s-ambassadog-1-4118303" title="">ambassadog</a>.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/global/commentisfree/2016/may/07/un-media-positive-news-catherine-bennett">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Is grit the true secret of success?</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/2016/may/07/is-grit-the-true-secret-of-success</link>
      <description>What does it take to do really well in life? The answer, says psychologist Angela Duckworth, is not innate talent but grit – something she learned the hard way<p>When Angela Duckworth was growing up, her dad often applied the word genius to his daughter. He did it at random moments, over dinner, watching TV or reading the newspaper, and the sentence was always the same: “You’re no genius!” Duckworth’s older sister and brother got it too. For Duckworth’s mother, an artist, the disparagement was adjusted to fit: “You’re no Picasso!”</p><p>This approach to raising children seems inauspicious but, in a funny way, it has worked pretty well. Duckworth, now 45, doesn’t recall how she answered her father, but her book Grit is her considered reply.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/2016/may/07/is-grit-the-true-secret-of-success">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>How to win an argument with a teenager</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/2016/may/07/how-to-win-an-argument-with-a-teenager</link>
      <description><p>Learn about the hypothalamus reaction and don’t be afraid to engage in a row</p><p><strong>1</strong> <strong>One thing that’s hard to understand</strong> – for parents and teenagers – is the hypothalamus reaction. This is when you get an extreme reaction that can happen quickly, in reaction to very little or even nothing. This explains why one minute you seem to have a reasonable child and the next, bam. Neural pathways go through a reordering in adolescence. There’s not much point trying to have a calm discussion during these “storms”. Just as you might defer a walk during a downpour, wait for the storm to pass before resuming a more reasonable discussion. During these explosive times, it feels, to the teen, that they are “fighting for their lives”.</p><p><strong>2 Don’t be afraid to have a row </strong>– some adolescents say they actually like arguing sometimes because it enables them to put their point of view across and “things can’t get any worse”. In other words, especially if you have a fairly reasonable child, an argument may be the only time they can tell you how they really feel.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/2016/may/07/how-to-win-an-argument-with-a-teenager">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <title>Junk food billboards, posters and digital ads targeting kids face ban</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/media/2016/may/13/junk-food-billboards-posters-and-digital-ads-targeting-kids-face-ban</link>
      <description><p>Advertising watchdog launches consultation to limit where adverts which promote products high in fat, salt and sugar to children can be shown</p><p>It could be goodbye to McDonald’s billboards, Pepsi posters and digital ads for Mars bars as the UK advertising watchdog launches a consultation on introducing tough new restrictions on marketing junk food to children.</p><p>The Committee of Advertising Practice – the code-setting body for all advertising in the UK that appears in any media except on TV and radio – has launched a consultation to limit where ads promoting products high in fat, salt and sugar can appear in media including the press, posters, billboards, magazines and online.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/media/2016/may/13/junk-food-billboards-posters-and-digital-ads-targeting-kids-face-ban">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <title>Top 10 budget cafes and restaurants in Belfast</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/travel/2016/may/13/top-10-budget-restaurants-cafes-belfast-northern-ireland</link>
      <description><p>Belfast is bursting with options for good, affordable food – from fish and chips and Tex-Mex to southern Indian and modern British. Updating <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/travel/2011/jul/07/belfast-budget-restaurants">our 2011 guide</a>, here are great places to eat for under £10 a head</p><p>Belfast foodies talk about Boojum with almost mystical reverence. That might seem OTT for what, at first glance, looks like a standard Tex-Mex, assembly-line burrito joint, but Boojum is a cut above that. The thick and tender, rope-like tangle of braised, shredded beef in my fat fist of a burrito was excellent. Like everything else in that wrap – from a stridently hot, smoky salsa to the spicy, tomato-based savoury rice – it had a fresh, well-defined flavour. No wonder Boojum is busy.<br><strong>Note: it also has a branch at Botanic Avenue</strong><br>• <em>Dishes from £5.10. 19-27 Chichester Street, 028-9023 0600, </em><a href="http://www.boojummex.com/"><em>boojummex.com</em></a><em>. Open daily 11.30am-10pm</em></p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/travel/2016/may/13/top-10-budget-restaurants-cafes-belfast-northern-ireland">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Olive Garden protests target drugged chickens and fair wages</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/sustainable-business/2016/may/12/olive-garden-protests-chicken-fair-wages</link>
      <description><p>Darden Restaurants, the largest full-service restaurant group in the US, is facing pressure to use antibiotic-free meat and pay better wages</p><p>Dozens of protesters picketed Olive Garden restaurants in seven cities on Thursday, including New York and Los Angeles, delivering a petition with 130,000 signatures that asks the chain to serve more vegetables, use meat raised with minimal use of antibiotics and pay its employees fair wages.</p><p> <span>Related: </span><a href="https://www.theguardian.com/sustainable-business/2015/dec/28/egg-industry-mcdonalds-free-range-hens-dunkin-donuts-general-mills-nestle">Why the egg industry is scrambling to set hens free</a> </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/sustainable-business/2016/may/12/olive-garden-protests-chicken-fair-wages">Continue reading...</a></description>
      <category domain="https://www.theguardian.com/sustainable-business/sustainable-business">Guardian sustainable business</category>
      <category domain="https://www.theguardian.com/business/business">Business</category>
      <category domain="https://www.theguardian.com/business/fooddrinks">Food & drink industry</category>

    <item>
      <title>What does it take to make a career out of brewing beer?</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/2016/may/12/beer-brewing-career-brewpubs-uk</link>
      <description><p>The rise of the brewpub shows no sign of stopping. Ahead of a members’ event in Cambridge, we hear from two head brewers</p><p>“For me, everything came together at the right time,” says Mark Burton, the head brewer at the <a draggable="true" href="http://www.thecambridgebrewhouse.com/">Cambridge Brew House</a>. “The company I was working for went into administration, I needed to make money immediately, so I turned my garage into a brewery and started selling to Cambridge free houses. I did that for a couple of years and then this job came up.”</p><p>Late last year, <a href="https://www.gov.uk/government/news/britain-becomes-brewing-powerhouse">the government declared</a> that Britain was a “brewing powerhouse”, with three breweries opening a week. The <a draggable="true" href="http://www.beerandpub.com/">British Beer and Pub Association</a> (BBPA) estimates that by the end of 2015, there were about 1,800 breweries in the UK. </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/2016/may/12/beer-brewing-career-brewpubs-uk">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Seasonal ravioli and orzotto recipes from chef Oliver Rowe</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/2016/may/12/seasonal-ravioli-and-orzotto-recipes-from-chef-oliver-rowe</link>
      <description><p>Italian cooking is about the bond between food and the land. Here, two recipes inspired by a revelatory summer in Tuscany make the most of any season </p><ul><li>Don’t miss the double-sized Italian issue of Guardian Cook this weekend<br></li></ul><p>The Italians have a lot to teach us about eating seasonally. Many of their dishes are adapted very easily from one season to the next. Pizza, pasta and risotto are all examples of these blank canvases, easily embellished with very little extra effort or know-how. As I write, I am reminded of trulli, the stone huts built for agricultural labourers in Puglia. These would have had very limited cooking facilities, making simple recipes that made the most of the changing seasons all the more important, cutting down on ingredients and equipment.</p><p>The year after I left university, after a long and rather dull stint as an admin assistant at Ofsted, I went to work in the kitchen at my cousin’s art school in Italy, which stood on the edge of the hilltop town of Casole in central Tuscany, overlooking sweeping sun-drenched umber and terracotta fields. It was there – during a summer of simple pleasures – that my passion for food was ignited.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/2016/may/12/seasonal-ravioli-and-orzotto-recipes-from-chef-oliver-rowe">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Ham and the curse of 'first world problems'</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/2016/may/12/ham-and-the-curse-of-first-world-problems</link>
      <description><p>It is possible to disapprove of machine-cut jamon and to feel outrage over Syria at the same time. Not that everyone agrees with me …</p><p>A few weeks ago<a href="https://mobile.twitter.com/jayrayner1/status/723796218883788800"> I tweeted disapprovingly</a> about a restaurant which was machine-cutting rather than hand-slicing its premium Spanish ham. This is a crime against jamon. I thought the world should know. Swiftly someone replied with three entirely predictable words: “First world problems.” Oh god. Here we go. One whinge about a food issue, and it’s time to reduce everything to a blunt moral calculus. Your service was too slow? First world problems. Your coffee was lukewarm? First world problems. Your bread is stale, your milk has soured, your portion size was meagre? First world bloody problems.</p><p>Let’s ignore the fact that nobody working in developmental politics or global aid describes impoverished parts of the globe as the “third world” any more, because it’s so damn patronising. Let’s focus instead on the sanctimonious self-regard of those who feel the need to point out that, while I’m fretting over the mis-slicing of pig, there is suffering in the world. I am thinking of ham. They are thinking only of the plight of Syria’s refugees.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/2016/may/12/ham-and-the-curse-of-first-world-problems">Continue reading...</a></description>
      <category domain="https://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/food-and-drink">Food & drink</category>
      <category domain="https://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/lifeandstyle">Life and style</category>
      <pubDate>Thu, 12 May 2016 11:00:12 GMT</pubDate>
      <guid>https://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/2016/may/12/ham-and-the-curse-of-first-world-problems</guid>

        <media:credit scheme="urn:ebu">Photograph: Alamy</media:credit>
      </media:content>
      <media:content width="460" url="https://i.guim.co.uk/img/media/10cf0e34df5fc90dc714171407902cba63676695/0_297_5079_3047/5079.jpg?w=460&q=55&auto=format&usm=12&fit=max&s=c953953a285a3ef9958a06c97daae732">

    <item>
      <title>Why I wish I hadn't learned how to make pizza</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/2016/may/12/why-i-wish-i-hadnt-learned-how-to-make-pizza</link>
      <description><p>Who knew that making your own pizza is actually cheaper and quicker than takeaway? Well Delia, obviously</p><ul><li>Don’t miss the double-sized Italian issue of Guardian Cook this weekend<br></li></ul><p>Unlike Delia, I have very few iron rules, but here’s one: you should never find out how the magic trick works. It’s not exciting if you know the lady hasn’t really been sawn in half or that the rabbit was in the magician’s sleeve all along. As long as you don’t know it’s all a trick, every wardrobe might, conceivably, have an enchanted kingdom at the back of it.</p><p>All of this is a convoluted way of saying: I really wish I hadn’t learned how to make pizza.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/2016/may/12/why-i-wish-i-hadnt-learned-how-to-make-pizza">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <title>Can a Craigslist for cucumbers tackle the UK's food waste?</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/media-network/2016/may/12/craigslist-uk-food-waste-sharing-economy-apps</link>
      <description><p>A raft of apps are aiming to recycle cosmetically challenged perishables and stop £5bn worth of food ending up in landfill</p><p>Where most people see a bruised banana, Saasha Celestial-One and Tessa Cook see a chance to share. Their new app, <a href="http://olioex.com/" rel="nofollow">Olio</a>, allows greengrocers, cafes, restaurants and neighbours to photograph and post food that is surplus, unappealing or close to expiry; other app users then request it and are notified where to pick it up.</p><p>According to the UN’s Food and Agricultural Organisation, <a href="http://www.fao.org/food-loss-and-food-waste/en/" rel="nofollow">a third of all food is wasted</a>, and more than half of that never reaches consumers. </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/media-network/2016/may/12/craigslist-uk-food-waste-sharing-economy-apps">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Louis Vuitton in Paris: regenerating athleisure</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2016/mar/09/louis-vuitton-makes-sportswear-looks-like-a-winner-paris-fashion-week</link>
      <description><p>The mighty luxury house’s Paris show aimed to reflect ‘the way women dress’ - and, remarkably, succeeded</p><p>In fashion, the art of making a look your own, rather than the wholesale adoption of the latest trend, is what distinguishes someone with style. </p><p>On the final day of Paris fashion week, Louis Vuitton gave a masterclass in making a hugely familiar trend – sportswear - its very own.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2016/mar/09/louis-vuitton-makes-sportswear-looks-like-a-winner-paris-fashion-week">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Stylewatch: Willow Smith at Chanel's Paris show</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2016/mar/09/stylewatch-willow-smith-at-chanels-paris-show</link>
      <description><p>Chanel’s new ambassador looks like a superhero – and is just what the fashion label needs</p><p>In the context of the tweedy, mannered vibe of Chanel’s <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2016/mar/08/chanel-in-paris-lagerfeld-revisits-coco-fashion-week">Paris show</a>, singer Willow Smith’s appearance on the Frow was a stylistic U-turn. She was a vision of futuristic nowness: pierced septum, robed cape, electric-blue Egyptian eyeliner and a catsuit that, if civilian space programmes did fashion lines, would work nicely in Nasa’s collection for next season. She basically looked like a badass superhero. The announcement that the 15-year-old daughter of Will Smith would be the <a href="https://www.instagram.com/p/BCsmYzJPNjU/?hl=en">new ambassador</a> for the fashion house seemed like a cheeky, Largerfeld-like nod to the old maxim of “out with the old, in with the new, babes”.</p><p>It also made total sense. Like her brother <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/culture/2016/jan/05/jaden-smith-skirt-gender-stereotypes-louis-vuitton-ad">Jaden</a>, she has been nothing but fashion forward since she <a href="https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ymKLymvwD2U">whipped her hair </a>back and forth at the tender age of nine. Experimenting with pastel-pink and platinum hair colours and shades of eye shadows in aubergine, she has lived out a life under the spotlight like a refined aesthete. Instead of scandalising the web with her TMZ-ish exploits, she has done her teen metamorphosis thing with a subtle grace, expressing herself via her <a href="https://www.instagram.com/gweelos/">Instagram</a>: a thing of beauty that, frankly, should be in the running to win the Turner prize.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2016/mar/09/stylewatch-willow-smith-at-chanels-paris-show">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Eight key trends from Paris: silk scarves, studenty velvets and flashy pleats</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2016/mar/08/eight-trends-paris-silk-scarves-studenty-velvets-flashy-pleats-fashion-week-trench-coats</link>
      <description>Paris fashion week featured weird trench coats, crooked hems and quilted biker jackets. And there was an up-all-night party-girl vibe thrown in for good measure<p>There’s something a bit rakish, a bit Quentin Crisp about a silk scarf. Though Crisp may have not been in mind <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2016/mar/03/chloe-shows-us-a-post-girly-world">at Chloé</a>, where the inspiration was Anne-France Dautheville, an adventurer who travelled across Europe on a motorbike in the 70s. Carine Roitfeld, spotted front row in a black one accessorised with a leopard-print coat and huge sunglasses, was a different matter. She totally gets the Crisp reference we reckon.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2016/mar/08/eight-trends-paris-silk-scarves-studenty-velvets-flashy-pleats-fashion-week-trench-coats">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Easy Riders, anoraks and patchworked jeans – the rise of post-chic Paris fashion</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2016/mar/08/easy-riders-anoraks-patchworked-jeans-post-chic-paris-fashion-instagrammed-catwalk-kanye-west</link>
      <description><p>The most Instagrammed piece on the catwalk this week is a green Balenciaga anorak, while, in the front row, Kanye West is the new Catherine Deneuve. How did Paris get so hard-edged?</p><p>All you really need to know, to get your head around Paris fashion week, is this: the most lusted-after, Instagram-liked piece on the catwalk this week was an anorak. At Balenciaga, new designer Demna Gvasalia’s vision for the most ultra-chic, super-refined Paris label was distilled in an <a href="http://www.businessoffashion.com/fashion-week/2016aw/balenciaga/collection/look/9">oversized anorak in a garish green-and-blue colour combination</a> which was a long, long way from the pale greys of Avenue Montaigne or the matt black of the Boulevard Saint Germain. And the audience loved it.</p><p> <span>Related: </span><a href="http://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2016/mar/08/eight-trends-paris-silk-scarves-studenty-velvets-flashy-pleats-fashion-week-trench-coats">Eight key trends from Paris: silk scarves, studenty velvets and flashy pleats</a> </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2016/mar/08/easy-riders-anoraks-patchworked-jeans-post-chic-paris-fashion-instagrammed-catwalk-kanye-west">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Chanel in Paris: Lagerfeld revisits Coco</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2016/mar/08/chanel-in-paris-lagerfeld-revisits-coco-fashion-week</link>
      <description><p>Airport lounge chic and Scottish estate references were on display at this self-referential show</p><p>The concept of the front row is understood even by those with just a whisper of an interest in fashion. While music venues have their moshpits and politics has its front bench, fashion has the Frow. A catwalk front row is a microcosm of all the narcissistic peacocking that exists in any industry. But here on the Frow, fashion’s top table, everything is laid bare for all to see. It appears that Karl Lagerfield is a designer who finds this never-ending fussing over seats an absolute delight. Why else would he do away with the row formatting at the Chanel show and make every single seat – all 3,500 of them – a front row? Certainly not for democratic reasons (that seems unlikely for a man at the helm of a billion-euro label selling bags with four-figure price tags) – it’s more likely for the insider fun of it.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2016/mar/08/chanel-in-paris-lagerfeld-revisits-coco-fashion-week">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Saint Laurent in Paris: the return of the 80s party girl</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2016/mar/08/saint-laurent-in-paris-the-return-of-the-80s-party-girl</link>
      <description><p>There’s the echo of a Roxy Music video in Hedi Slimane’s latest, and possibly last, collection for fashion house</p><p>Since 2012, when designer <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/fashion/hedi-slimane">Hedi Slimane</a> began his reboot of the Saint Laurent brand, the label has been closely linked with music. Whether that be the young indie bands which populated the front row of his shows to the chagrin of uptight fashion editors banished to the rows behind them, or the designs themselves which are frequently dosed with gig culture – Glastonbury wellies and Courtney Love tiaras were a feature of his last show in Paris. Advocates of the brand are often those who <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/fashion/fashion-blog/2016/feb/11/justin-bieber-glitter-and-velvet-saint-laurent-makes-its-la-debut">play music for a living</a>, from Justin Bieber to Keith Richards.</p><p>So it was significant that at the Saint Laurent show in Paris on Monday evening – the second part of the brand’s fall collection which began in blockbuster gig fashion in LA last month – that there was no catwalk music at all. Instead, the soundtrack was simply the voice of Benedicte de Ginestous announcing the arrival of each of the outfits. “Numero un ... number one,” she declared in a tone at once overly dramatic but also compelling. The significance of this device was not lost on the audience seated on personalised chairs in marble-heavy salons – de Ginestous announced the numbers of each look for Yves Saint Laurent’s couture shows between 1977 and 2002.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2016/mar/08/saint-laurent-in-paris-the-return-of-the-80s-party-girl">Continue reading...</a></description>
      <category domain="https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/fashion">Fashion</category>

      <category domain="https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/fashion-industry">Fashion industry</category>
      <pubDate>Tue, 08 Mar 2016 10:58:40 GMT</pubDate>
      <guid>https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2016/mar/08/saint-laurent-in-paris-the-return-of-the-80s-party-girl</guid>
      <media:content width="140" url="https://i.guim.co.uk/img/media/945010893706be058152fe9f5a6dd3c9105d9de9/0_156_3280_1969/master/3280.jpg?w=140&q=55&auto=format&usm=12&fit=max&s=f90f42dd238603c0ddda6d3b233f7786">
        <media:credit scheme="urn:ebu">Photograph: Martin Bureau/AFP/Getty Images</media:credit>
      </media:content>
      <media:content width="460" url="https://i.guim.co.uk/img/media/945010893706be058152fe9f5a6dd3c9105d9de9/0_156_3280_1969/master/3280.jpg?w=460&q=55&auto=format&usm=12&fit=max&s=7d238988979e37702ab8b0758f1bd976">

    <item>
      <title>Stella McCartney show: designer's clothes reflect how real women live</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2016/mar/07/paris-fashion-week-stella-mccartney-show-designer-clothes-real-women</link>
      <description><p>With her label in rude health, Paris fashion week show adopts a greatest hits approach – but if that sounds dull, it wasn’t</p><p>The disconnect between the invitations to Stella McCartney’s shows and the tone of the show itself has long been acknowledged by insiders at Paris fashion week. This season’s – a digital display with the word “invites” flashing across the screen – is pure silliness. </p><p>Monday’s event, on the other hand, was a serious business. While the show notes talked about “sensual with a sense of humour and a tomboy side” the collection worked on that classic commercial adage: if it ain’t broke, don’t fix it. </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2016/mar/07/paris-fashion-week-stella-mccartney-show-designer-clothes-real-women">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>San Francisco on a budget: readers’ travel tips</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/travel/2016/may/12/san-francisco-budget-affordable-food-hotel-spa-readers</link>
      <description><p>Despite rampant gentrification, the City by the Bay still has some great affordable experiences, if you know where to look. Readers share their best bargains </p><p>For affordable shelter and transport, just bring a tent and a bike. There’s a <a href="http://www.parksconservancy.org/visit/camp/#Bicentennial">free campsite</a> just a mile away from the northern (Marin county) end of Golden Gate, where a visitor centre offers clean washrooms. From there, cycle across the bridge and catch a <a href="https://www.sfbike.org/resources/bikes-transit/">bike-rack-equipped Muni bus</a>. You can have the run of the whole bus system for a $31 <a href="https://www.sfmta.com/getting-around/transit/fares-passes/visitor-day-passes">three-day bus pass</a>; the bike-and-bus combo gets you anywhere in town.<br><strong>Vbdsun</strong></p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/travel/2016/may/12/san-francisco-budget-affordable-food-hotel-spa-readers">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Oakland city guide: what to see plus the best bars, hotels and restaurants</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/travel/2016/may/12/oakland-california-holiday-guide-usa</link>
      <description><p>The city across the bay has shed its inferiority complex and offers plenty of reasons to visit. In fact, you can now skip San Francisco altogether, and fly to Oakland direct from the UK</p><p>Oakland is changing fast. Once known merely as San Francisco’s rough-and-tough neighbour – the birthplace of the Black Panther movement and home of the Hell’s Angels – it is rapidly becoming the most fashionable place in northern California. Those who can’t afford the tech-boom prices across the Bay are making their home in the city and, greeted by an array of new restaurants and bars, a thriving arts scene, and a strong sense of energy and community. Gertrude Stein might have said about her childhood hometown that “There is no there there”, but, these days, Oakland’s residents and visitors are more likely to shout “Come here here!”</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/travel/2016/may/12/oakland-california-holiday-guide-usa">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Interview with a Bookstore: Albertine, a little Paris in New York</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/books/booksblog/2016/may/09/interview-with-a-bookstore-albertine-a-little-paris-in-new-york</link>
      <description><p>A bookshop opened to promote French literature in the American metropolis is full of eccentric regulars and great stories – Albertine’s booksellers share them, and give French book recommendations </p><ul><li>Interview with a Bookstore from <a href="http://lithub.com/">Literary Hub</a> is part of the <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/books/series/guardian-books-network">Guardian Books Network</a> <br></li></ul><ul><li><strong>Scroll down for the staff recommendations shelf</strong></li></ul><p><a href="http://www.albertine.com/">Albertine</a> is a foundation that opened in September in 2014, hosted by the Cultural Services of the French Embassy in New York. The store was opened to help promote French culture in New York, especially the literary arts. But also to make books more easily available to Francophone people in New York, especially since the store that had been in Rockefeller Center closed several years ago. The store has been profiled in <a href="http://www.newyorker.com/books/page-turner/albertine-reparue-french-bookshop-new-york">The New Yorker</a>, <a href="http://www.nytimes.com/2014/10/10/books/french-embassy-starts-a-festival-and-albertine-a-bookstore.html">The New York Times</a> and all over the French media.</p><p><strong>What is your favorite section of the store?</strong></p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/books/booksblog/2016/may/09/interview-with-a-bookstore-albertine-a-little-paris-in-new-york">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Road trips and fire pits: discovering the secrets of BBQ in Nashville</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/travel/2016/may/06/road-trips-fire-pits-secrets-of-bbq-nashville-tennessee</link>
      <description><p>Shauna Guinn and her partner searched the deep south for the best American barbecue before opening their own joint in the deep south of ... Wales</p><p><strong>My partner Sam and I wanted to discover the secret of American barbecue.</strong> We gave up our jobs in the UK and busked our way from California to the deep south. The US version of a barbecue is quite different to ours, it’s all about smoking meat in a “pit” for a long time at low temperatures.</p><p><strong>Everyone thinks Nashville is a little honky-tonk town in the middle of Tennessee</strong>. It’s actually quite a commercial place, the beating heart of all the major record companies – there are cowboys walking around with guitars and Stetsons, but they tend to be commercial artists. And it’s not just country music – Jack White from the White Stripes has his main studio there. Broadway, the main strip, is cheesy and tacky, but great for a laugh. One of the most famous bars is <a href="http://www.tootsies.net/">Tootsies</a>, known for craft beer and moonshine. Every bar in Nashville has live bands, and the musicianship is unbelievable, even at the smallest joints.<br></p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/travel/2016/may/06/road-trips-fire-pits-secrets-of-bbq-nashville-tennessee">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/travel/2016/may/04/san-francisco-travel-tips-competition</link>
      <description><p>San Francisco’s colourful reputation has suffered in the wake of gentrification from Silicon Valley. Help us shed some light on the affordable and independent hotels, restaurants and other genuine local spots</p><p>Rents have risen harshly in <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/us-news/san-francisco">San Francisco</a> over the past few years, pricing out the smaller businesses and eccentric neighbourhoods that made The City unique.     <item>
      <title>Top 10 US mid-Atlantic national and state parks</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/travel/2016/may/03/top-10-us-national-state-parks-new-jersey-pennsylvania-delaware-maryland</link>
      <description><p>The eastern states of Pennsylvania, New Jersey, Delaware and Maryland offer green spaces with stunning peaks and waterfalls, as well as wonderful wildlife</p><p>The Delaware river forms part of the border between Pennsylvania and New Jersey. In the 1960s the Army Corps of Engineers proposed building a dam along the flood-prone section of river between the New York state line and the coal mining town of East Stroudsburg, Pennsylvania. This would have created a 37-mile lake between Pennsylvania and New Jersey to be called Tocks Island national recreation area. In preparation for flooding the valley, more than 15,000 people were displaced from their homes. Then a geologic study revealed that the proposed dam was on top of several active fault lines and the project was scrapped. In 1978, the property was transferred to the National Park Service and renamed the Delaware Water Gap national recreation area. Today, the park protects 70,000 acres of forest and farmland, 40 miles of the Delaware river and 28 miles of the Appalachian Trail.<br><strong>Top tip</strong> Many picturesque hamlets and villages that stood along the Delaware river were lost to the dam project but some historic buildings remain. The quaint village of Bevans now stands as the <a href="http://www.petersvalley.org/index.cfm">Peters Valley School of Craft</a>, where blacksmithing, woodworking and weaving are taught and practised. Take a tour of the historic grounds on summer weekends or sign up for a two- to five-day workshop between May and September.<br>• <a href="https://www.nps.gov/dewa/index.htm"><em>nps.gov/dewa</em></a></p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/travel/2016/may/03/top-10-us-national-state-parks-new-jersey-pennsylvania-delaware-maryland">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>The foodie traveller ... on the best gumbo in New Orleans</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/travel/2016/apr/24/new-orleans-best-gumbo-louisiana</link>
      <description><p>This iconic stew is ‘the history of Louisiana in a bowl’ and served in every NOLA eaterie worth its salt – but head to Mid-City for top-notch versions</p><p>When New Orleanian actor Wendell Pierce (star of Treme and The Wire) was asked how food had helped Louisiana recover from Hurricane Katrina, he replied: “It’s all about creativity. Taking what little you have, and creating something wonderful. That’s what gumbo is: the scraps of the table, with a little oil and burnt flour – one of the finest culinary treats ever ...”</p><p>Gumbo, essentially a stew, is the history of Louisiana in a bowl. As with many dishes, its origins are disputed. Some say it’s a derivative of bouillabaisse, the Provençal fish stew. It’s more likely, however, to have arrived with the first wave of African slaves in Mobile, Alabama, in around 1720, as an evolution of <em>soupou kandia</em>, a Senegalese fish-and-okra stew (the word for okra in several west African languages is <em>n’gombo</em>). The dish’s evolution reflected the changing face of Louisiana, with the French-speaking Acadians, Spanish and even German settlers adding to the pot.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/travel/2016/apr/24/new-orleans-best-gumbo-louisiana">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>10 epic long-distance walks around the world</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/travel/2016/apr/23/top-long-distance-walks-worldwide</link>
      <description><p>From the Highlands to the Himalayas, these hikes take in some of the world’s most spectacular landscapes. They’re not for the faint-hearted, but keen trekkers will love the challenges posed by each<br><strong>More great walks: <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/travel/2016/apr/23/10-best-walks-holidays-in-europe">Europe</a> | <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/travel/2016/apr/23/british-walks-uk-family-long-distance-paths-trails">UK</a> | <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/travel/gallery/2016/apr/23/boots-kit-for-walkers-in-pictures">best kit</a></strong></p><p>The <a href="http://www.makalutrekking.com/makalu-base-camp-trekking.html">trek to the base of the fifth highest mountain in the world</a> leads from dense rain forests over steep passes, to high pastures below glacier-clad peaks. Although only 125 miles long, the trek is tough as it involves an ascent of more than 7,000 metres and remote and rugged terrain. Once over the 4,100-metre Shipton La (pass), the route descends into the spectacular Barun river valley and climbs to the tongue of the Barun glacier, below the great dark wedge of Makalu.As the only way to get back is over the Shipton La, there is a degree of commitment not required on many treks. There are few villages and teahouses, making this even more of a wilderness trek. It passes through every climatic zone, from tropical forest to tundra and is a wonderful way to experience the huge range of environments found in Nepal.<br>•<em> Twelve-day guided trek (14 nights total) with </em><a href="https://www.keadventure.com/holidays/nepal-trekking-makalu-basecamp-shipton-la"><em>KE Adventure</em></a><em> in October or November, £2,445pp full-board </em></p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/travel/2016/apr/23/top-long-distance-walks-worldwide">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <title>Interview with a Bookstore: The Last Bookstore in Los Angeles</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/books/2016/apr/11/interview-with-a-bookstore-the-last-bookstore-los-angeles</link>
      <description><p>Which books would you like to find in the last bookstore on a post-apocalyptic earth? This was the premise behind the birth of The Last Bookstore in California</p><p>Interview with a Bookstore from <a href="http://lithub.com/">Literary Hub</a> is part of the <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/books/series/guardian-books-network">Guardian Books Network</a></p><ul><li><strong>Scroll down for the staff recommendations shelf</strong><br></li></ul><p>Before LA’s <a href="http://lastbookstorela.com/">the Last Bookstore</a> opened its first brick-and-mortar store in December 2009, the staff sold used books online, out of owners Josh and Heidi Spencer’s home. In June 2011, the team moved to their current location in a former bank building. The goal was to create a bookstore that would contain a collection of what Josh would want to find in “the last bookstore on earth.” </p><p>Here, its booksellers talk to Literary Hub about the store’s past and present, and about great books. </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/books/2016/apr/11/interview-with-a-bookstore-the-last-bookstore-los-angeles">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Experience: IVF gave me a heart attack</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/2016/may/06/ivf-gave-me-heart-attack-at-25</link>
      <description><p>When my left arm started to go numb, I suspected a heart attack, but I was only 25, so decided I had to be overreacting</p><p>I was 15 when I was diagnosed with severe <a href="http://www.nhs.uk/conditions/Polycystic-ovarian-syndrome/Pages/Introduction.aspx">polycystic ovarian syndrome</a>, a condition that means cysts grow on your ovaries. I hadn’t started my periods and was told it was unlikely I ever would. The gynaecologist said I’d need intervention when the time came to have a family, and put me on the pill to stop the cysts growing. It didn’t bother me at the time – I think my mum was more upset than I was.</p><p>At 21, I fell in love, and when we got married four years later, we went to a fertility clinic that claimed high success rates. They put me on stimulation drugs to induce ovulation – the same drugs as for IVF, but without the need for the egg collection. We were so hopeful it would work first time that I bought baby toys and clothes. When it didn’t, we felt devastated, but the clinic said doubling the dose should do the trick. I expressed concerns because my family has a history of blood clots, but they said it was fine. I was more closely monitored the second time, but again I didn’t get pregnant.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/2016/may/06/ivf-gave-me-heart-attack-at-25">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>How to cook the perfect aloo gobi</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/wordofmouth/2016/may/12/how-to-cook-the-perfect-aloo-gobi</link>
      <description><p>This Punjabi potato and cauliflower curry is now a prized dish across India and Pakistan. But for the best texture, should the potatoes be waxy or floury? And which spices bring out its comforting warmth?</p><p>According to chef <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/2016/feb/23/vivek-singh-indian-dishes-with-stories-to-tell">Vivek Singh</a>, this hearty cauliflower and potato dish is probably “the most common and basic vegetable curry you will find anywhere in India”. Cheap, filling and only <a href="http://www.veganuary.com/eating-out/indian-cuisine/">coincidentally vegan</a>, it’s a recipe you definitely need in your repertoire.</p><p>The problem is, although aloo gobi has its origins in the <a href="http://www.nytimes.com/2014/03/23/travel/a-culinary-pilgrimage-to-punjab.html?_r=0">Punjab</a>, it’s now a firm favourite across India and Pakistan – and, as Singh observes, “one of the disadvantages of its universal appeal is that there is no such thing as a universal recipe”. Consider this, then, as one very good place to start.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/wordofmouth/2016/may/12/how-to-cook-the-perfect-aloo-gobi">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Beauty: the best lightweight facial sunblocks | Sali Hughes</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2016/may/07/best-lightweight-facial-sunblock-beauty-sali-hughes</link>
      <description><p>These days, we’re spoiled for choice </p><p>I can almost chart the arrival of spring by the dramatically increasing number of tweets, letters and emails asking for sunblock recommendations. Almost without exception, men and women say they want something that feels weightless and non-greasy, and that won’t slide off the face as soon as humidity strikes. My own requirements are much the same, though I’d want something broad spectrum (ie, protecting against both UVA and UVB; the law demands only the latter) that doesn’t peel off in tiny balls as soon as I try to blend makeup over the top (so wearying).</p><p>While I’m heartened that readers want to protect&nbsp;their faces in the sun, until a year or two ago I could rarely deliver on their ideal texture. Nowadays, though, I’m spoiled for choice, and the quality of formulations is increasing year on year. Ticking every box is the wonderful <a href="http://www.johnlewis.com/murad-luminous-shield-spf-50-pa-30ml/p2507151" title=""><strong>Murad Luminous Shield SPF50</strong></a> (£55). I should warn you that this particular product comes from the White Brilliance range, which hints heavily at that glaring and almost universally unflattering lavender-white&nbsp;imparted by many sunblocks, so rendering it&nbsp;entirely unsuitable for non-white skins, but I&nbsp;promise that here the name is misleading (I was so alarmed that I forced a dark-skinned friend to wear it for a day and she looked great).</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2016/may/07/best-lightweight-facial-sunblock-beauty-sali-hughes">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Ask Eva says goodbye: seven lessons I learned from answering your questions</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/2016/mar/10/ask-eva-final-column-online-dating-10-things-know</link>
      <description><p>I’m signing off after more than a year of helping you swipe right (or not), but first, here’s what I learned from being your electronic agony aunt</p><p>When I started writing this column just over a year ago, I wasn’t sure how long it would last. How many questions, I wondered, would people really have about online dating? Answer: many! From getting started with online dating in middle age, to the ethics of juggling multiple online paramours, I heard about the anxious-making unreturned right-swipe, the ecstasy of finding partners for niche sexual activities and the challenge of finding partners from particular ethnic groups; I pondered the trouble of falling in love with people who are probably robots, and considered how to make your profile stand out in a field of shirtless Netflix fans. </p><p>Today, I’m signing off, but before I go, here are the most important things I learned in my year as your electronic agony aunt.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/2016/mar/10/ask-eva-final-column-online-dating-10-things-know">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Stylewatch: Hole in 1995</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2016/may/10/stylewatch-hole-in-1995</link>
      <description><p>It’s rumoured that Courtney Love’s band might reform – making this the perfect time to revive their influential 90s look </p><p>Courtney Love has always been a woman with the appeal of Marmite. The love/hate thing dates back to the 90s – and has links to a style of dress that came to be known as “<a draggable="true" href="http://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2016/mar/11/90s-are-back-how-to-get-the-look">Kinderwhore</a>”. Think slip dresses, ripped tights, peroxide hair and lipstick applied with the dexterity of a six-year-old. </p><p>Love was courting controversy from the start with the thrift-store mixture of childlike shapes, cute hairgrips and the rips and tears of punk, and she was also challenging the slick glamour of 80s femininity. The look was worn by women in the grunge scene – including <a draggable="true" href="http://www.theguardian.com/music/2015/feb/03/cult-heroes-babes-in-toylands-kat-bjelland-overlooked-90s-punk-powerhouse">Kat Bjelland of Babes in Toyland</a>, who supposedly coined the term – they were grown-ups dressed as dolls left out in the garden over night: pretty but grubby. The look went viral when it was faithfully replicated by Hole’s fans, who had been watching the <a draggable="true" href="https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=mS1Ckczz0LQ">Miss World</a> video on repeat. Those haters inevitably hated.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2016/may/10/stylewatch-hole-in-1995">Continue reading...</a></description>
      <category domain="https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/fashion">Fashion</category>
      <category domain="https://www.theguardian.com/music/courtney">Courtney Love</category>
      <category domain="https://www.theguardian.com/music/music">Music</category>
      <category domain="https://www.theguardian.com/culture/culture">Culture</category>

    <item>
      <title>Don’t think you’re lucky? Think again | Oliver Burkeman</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/2016/may/06/dont-think-youre-lucky-think-again</link>
      <description><p>You probably think you got where you are today through willpower and elbow grease. But what about chance, asks Oliver Burkeman</p><p>Do you feel lucky? The answer, well known to psychologists, is that you probably don’t. You probably think you got where you are today through willpower and elbow grease. We chronically underestimate luck’s role, and this seems to get worse the richer we get; <a href="http://www.people-press.org/2014/01/23/most-see-inequality-growing-but-partisans-differ-over-solutions/">surveys show</a> that the wealthiest are least likely to attribute their fortunes to, well, good fortune. They also seem to be meaner: <a href="http://wheels.blogs.nytimes.com/2013/08/12/the-rich-drive-differently-a-study-suggests/">one ingenious study</a> found drivers of luxury cars were more likely to cut others off than those in cheaper vehicles.</p><p>It’s hardly surprising many such people oppose taxation and government spending: why should others get a handout if they didn’t need one? The ironic result is that they vote against the very policies that helped them get lucky to begin with. In <a href="http://www.theatlantic.com/magazine/archive/2016/05/why-luck-matters-more-than-you-might-think/476394/">a recent Atlantic essay</a>, Robert Frank, an economist who has studied attitudes to chance, quoted EB White: “Luck is not something you can mention in the presence of self-made men.”</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/2016/may/06/dont-think-youre-lucky-think-again">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <category domain="https://www.theguardian.com/science/science">Science</category>
      <pubDate>Fri, 06 May 2016 14:00:29 GMT</pubDate>
      <guid>https://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/2016/may/06/dont-think-youre-lucky-think-again</guid>

        <media:credit scheme="urn:ebu">Photograph: Thomas Pullin for the Guardian</media:credit>

    <item>
      <title>Why I love… Michaela Coel</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/2016/may/07/michaela-coel-crush-black-mirror-comedy</link>
      <description><p>Coel is fearless. No joke is too risque, no comedic situation too outrageous to explore in pursuit of the funny </p><p>Generally speaking, I love being surprised. It’s an increasingly hard&nbsp;thing to do, because the world&nbsp;is so predictable and my cynicism is a hard shell to breach. But sometimes along comes a&nbsp;breath&nbsp;of fresh air that cracks it&nbsp;just&nbsp;a little, before coaxing it wide open.</p><p>The most recent fragrant breeze? Her name is <a href="http://www.imdb.com/name/nm3948190/">Michaela Coel</a>, 28, a one-woman powerhouse. I first saw her in the raucous, incredibly filthy and funny award-winning E4 sitcom she created and starred in, <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/tv-and-radio/2015/oct/06/chewing-gum-michaela-coel">Chewing Gum</a>. But that’s just&nbsp;her highest-profile gig. Her talent is multi-pronged: she’s <a href="https://rts.org.uk/tags/michaela-coel">a Royal Television Society award-winning actor</a>, <a href="http://www.bbc.co.uk/programmes/p03kwcl1">talented spoken-word&nbsp;artist</a> and a playwright&nbsp;(Chewing Gum’s&nbsp;first life was as a one-woman stage show called&nbsp;<a href="http://www.theguardian.com/stage/2014/mar/19/chewing-gum-dreams-theatre-review">Chewing Gum&nbsp;Dreams</a>). Last&nbsp;month she won a Bafta, <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/tv-and-radio/2016/mar/30/baftas-2016-therell-be-no-diversity-row-but-poldark-and-downton-abbey-fans-will-be-angry">crowning her as TV’s breakthrough star</a>.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/2016/may/07/michaela-coel-crush-black-mirror-comedy">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <title>The eco guide to cruises | Lucy Siegle</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2016/may/01/eco-guide-to-cruises</link>
      <description><p>Before you embark on a cruise, there are serious ethical questions to ask…</p><p>Ahoy, my ageing hearties. Increasing numbers of mega liners are being built. These monster ships can carry, entertain and feed 5,000 passengers at a time. Meanwhile <a href="https://www.tourismconcern.org.uk/cruise-tourism-whats-below-the-surface/">research from Tourism Concern</a> shows that the older vessels are responsible for 36 times as many greenhouse gas emissions per passenger kilometre than Eurostar and three and a half times more than a long-haul flight. And this is just the start of a long ethical rap sheet.</p><p>So here are the questions to ask before setting sail that nobody does…</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2016/may/01/eco-guide-to-cruises">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <description><p>Trainers love a lunge. Every trainer in the world will get you doing lunges at one point or other</p><p><strong>What is it? </strong>A sort of one one-legged squat.     <item>
      <title>A letter to … My mother, who cheated on my father and doesn’t know I know</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/2016/may/07/a-letter-to-my-mother-who-cheated-on-my-father-and-doesnt-know-i-know</link>
      <description><p>The letter you always wanted to write</p><p>He came into our lives and I heard you joking with our next-door neighbour about how attractive he was. I saw how you wore more makeup than usual when he came to our house. I saw the furtive glances across the garden and I remember so clearly the time you brought him to the house when Dad was away. He sat stiffly at our kitchen table with us, and the others were too young to think anything of it, but I knew this was his audition in your mind. Could he replace your husband of 15 years?</p><p>I was a bright 12 year old. Top of my class in fact. And yet you believed me naive enough to think that he was just a friend.&nbsp;</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/2016/may/07/a-letter-to-my-mother-who-cheated-on-my-father-and-doesnt-know-i-know">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>What I’m really thinking: the masseur</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/2016/may/07/masseur-what-really-thinking</link>
      <description><p>I am constantly amazed when clients come in wearing boxers that come down to the knee or bikini tops. I’m not at all interested in your private parts</p><p>As you enter the spa, the last thing on your mind is to cause offence, but imagine how it&nbsp;feels to have you take one look at me and immediately ask for a female masseuse. Don’t you realise we’re all professionals, and that I am just as able to give a caring and sensitive massage as my female colleagues? No matter that their schedules are already twice as busy as mine, I now have to spend the lost hour folding sheets and regretting loss of income.</p><p>I wish clients would take greater care to bathe, too. I’ve been doing this job for 20 years, and I’m still amazed that some people come straight from the beach, all covered in sand. And those ever so subtle farts from a barely digested lunch are an affront to my senses.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/2016/may/07/masseur-what-really-thinking">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>From oddballs to Indiana Jones: my online search for love</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/2016/apr/02/from-oddballs-to-indiana-jones-my-online-search-for-love</link>
      <description><p>Two years ago and recently divorced, Stella Grey took up internet dating. Eventually, she met Mr Right but it wasn’t an easy ride. Here’s what she learned along the way during her mid-life ex-wife column</p><p>Online dating at 50 was much harder than I thought it would be. I was prepared for hard, but I wasn’t prepared for going down a rabbit hole to another land, or its perpetual magic realism. In all, I spent 693 days there, from signing up to the first site to arriving at what would prove to be the last first date.</p><p>I rolled up my sleeves and did online dating thoroughly. I’m project-oriented by nature and so it took a lot of time. Day on day, week on week, I trawled the sites for men to talk to, answered approaches, and got into correspondence. Sometimes, I even met people. The first period was amusingly anecdote-worthy. I found incompatible men, talked to some oddballs, and had a few knockbacks.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/2016/apr/02/from-oddballs-to-indiana-jones-my-online-search-for-love">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>My son’s girlfriend has anorexia and I worry about the effect on him</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/2016/may/06/my-sons-girlfriend-has-anorexia-and-i-worry-about-the-effect-on-him</link>
      <description>He seems to be coping but I think he’s too young to deal with this complicated illness alone. Annalisa Barbieri advises a reader<p><strong>My adult son is in a long-term relationship with his girlfriend, who has a serious eating disorder. When he first met her she was slim but healthy. Unbeknown to him, she had recently recovered from anorexia. Sadly, over the past few years, the anorexia has returned and she is now extremely frail and underweight. She has recently committed to an inpatient plan but it will be a long process and she is still entrenched in her eating habits and resistant to change, despite having had therapy for almost a year. I am very hopeful that she will be successful, but if she isn’t I worry how this will affect him.</strong></p><p><strong>I know that recovery from anorexia is a long and painful process and inevitably her illness will have a great impact on both their lives. Although her friends and family are supportive, he is the one who sees her every day and has to watch her starve herself, which must be very painful. I don’t often see him on his own and try not to talk about it too much as he seems to prefer to deal with it by pretending it’s not happening and making elaborate travel and holiday plans for the two of them, which seems to me a form of escapism. I suggested he might want therapy or to go to a support group but he says he has a few good friends he can speak to if necessary. </strong></p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/2016/may/06/my-sons-girlfriend-has-anorexia-and-i-worry-about-the-effect-on-him">Continue reading...</a></description>
      <category domain="https://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/family">Family</category>
      <category domain="https://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/lifeandstyle">Life and style</category>

    <item>
      <title>I have come out as gay, but no one seems to want to love me</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/2016/may/06/come-out-as-gay-no-one-wants-to-love-me</link>
      <description><p>I am torn between my religious upbringing and being out, and am disappointed at the emphasis on sex in gay culture. Why can’t someone see the real loving me?</p><p>I am 26 and I came out as gay at the end of last year. I am from a religious background and I feel stuck between two realms and I can’t find the appropriate balance. Seeking a lasting loving relationship for a 26-year-old virgin is not as easy as I thought. With so much preference for everyone to be physical in gay culture, I feel disappointed and even more alone in a foreign country. Dating websites only add to my sorrow and despair. From the religion side, it seems everyone hates me for who I love. I feel I can’t even go back nor move forward, since it seems I am not worth loving, even though I am a talented, loving, caring individual. If someone could see beyond the appearance, they would be see my inner beauty, but no one bothers.</p><p><em>• When leaving a message on this page, please be sensitive to the fact that you are responding to a real person in the grip of a real-life dilemma, who wrote to Private Lives asking for help, and may well view your comments here. Please consider especially how your words or the tone of your message could be perceived by someone in this situation, and be aware that comments that appear to be disruptive or disrespectful to the individual concerned will be removed.</em></p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/2016/may/06/come-out-as-gay-no-one-wants-to-love-me">Continue reading...</a></description>
